awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Community Role In Emergence Of Complex Societies
awd_abstract_narration:
This research addresses the role of large-scale public architecture in the emergence of early communities and the formation of complex societies. Monumental construction remains one of the most widely recognized markers of settled agricultural communities and relationships of inequality which structure labor organization. Thus, it is often viewed as an outcome of social complexity. However, several noteworthy early instances of monumental constructions throughout the world indicate impressive projects could be accomplished through cooperative relationships among largely mobile and minimally stratified populations. These findings require an adjusted framework for interpretation of the social relationships between individuals engaging in the construction and use of public spaces and the role of constructed space in promoting new social relationships. Does the act of creating and interacting in a constructed space bind people together in new ways? Do such constructions promote integration across broader regions, as well as local communities? This dissertation project will investigate the role of public architecture in local community formation and regional integration at an archaeological site. In an effort to increase analysis capacity and offer laboratory experience to aspiring researchers, local students will participate in the research.

The proposed project investigates how the development of the public architecture relates to markers of increased community integration by focusing on evidence for labor investment, activity, ritual deposits, and regional interaction. A key architectural complex at the site dates to very early in its history. Its foundation appears to predate household construction at the site and indicates the complex was integral to the formation of a local settlement. Changes in the architectural materials and arrangement of the complex correlate with important temporal and political regional changes providing a fitting archaeological context to examine the long-term relationship between public architecture and integration and the local and regional scales. In this project, shifts in labor investment and activity within a public plaza-structure complex will be examined as markers of local community development while increased similarity in ritual deposits and ceramic styles between those found within the site and those reported from others in the region will be examined as markers of regional integration. Indicators of change will be anchored in time through the use of statistical modeling in building and improving the site chronology. Activity residues, derived from geochemical testing of samples, collected from buried floors across the site, add an important dataset to the study of early monuments and elucidate additional aspects of their uses and meanings to local populations. Integrating this dataset within systematic examination of traditional archaeological measurers derived from architectural excavations and analysis of recovered artifacts expands understanding of early construction and stands to further understanding of the diverse drives contributing to social complexity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research addressed the role of large-scale public architecture in the emergence of early communities and the formation of complex societies in the Mesoamerican past. Monumental construction brings about images of leaders directing and organizing labor within settled agricultural communities. As a result, early large constructions are often viewed as an outcome of social complexity. However, several noteworthy early instances of monumental constructions throughout the world indicate impressive projects could be accomplished through cooperative relationships among minimally stratified populations. These findings require an adjusted framework for interpretation of the social relationships between individuals engaging in the construction and use of public spaces and the role of constructed space in promoting new social relationships. Tulane University doctoral candidate, Borislava Simova, worked to apply this framework in an examination of an early ritual complex from the ancient Maya site of Actuncan, Belize. During the span of the project, Simova worked to broaden the impact of the research by presenting on findings to a diverse audience of Belizean and foreign researchers, tour guides, and enthusiasts committed to preserving Belize?s cultural heritage and furthering the development of an informed tourism industry. Simova also worked to create more professional development opportunities within the archaeological project for local students.

The ritual complex under investigation, located in Actuncan?s monumental core, was founded at approximately 1000 BCE, placing it among the earliest constructions identified in the eastern Maya Lowlands. Additionally, its foundation appears to predate household construction at the site, indicating the complex was an early component in the formation of a local settlement. In this project, Simova investigated how the development of the public architecture related to markers of increased community integration by focusing on evidence for labor investment, ritual activity, and regional interaction. Labor calculations for the early version of the complex revealed that although the earthen architecture required more people to be involved than would have lived in the site core, the number of people and hours worked would have been substantially lower than for later stages. Over time, more labor-intensive materials used in construction required a larger labor force and more coordination and planning in preparation for construction. The early building activity, however, could have provided opportunities to build new relationships and plan for future action in using and modifying the complex.

Activity residues, derived from geochemical testing of samples, collected from buried floors across the plaza of the complex, add an important dataset to the study of the activity that took place within early monuments. In this study, analysis of the chemical signatures of prehistoric activity showed greater diversity in activity types in the earliest plaza floor, measured by combinations and distribution of chemical signatures across the plazas. Subsequent tested floors show fewer signatures, indicating fewer, more structured activity types. This change between plaza floors is interpreted to represent a shift from a less-structured communal space to a special-purpose ritual space within a growing settlement. The early diversity in activity could have allowed participants to experiment with different practices and develop shared modes of engaging with the public space.

The critical changes between the stages of the ritual complex were anchored in regional developments through the use of detailed ceramic analysis and radiocarbon dating of burned material from the complex. Together, these dating techniques produced an improved timeline of construction and use of the complex and the site of Actuncan, useful for examining integration at a regional scale. More importantly, the datasets used in this study provide further understanding of the diverse development of communities by indicating greater opportunities for cooperative, minimally structured interactions in the development of social complexity.
